abstract.text: An object that provides physics-related capabilities and animations for its dynamic items, and provides the context for those animations.

inlineContent.text: A
dynamic item
is any iOS or custom object that conforms to the
protocol. The
and

classes implement this protocol in iOS 7 and later. You can implement this protocol to use a dynamic animator with custom objects for such purposes as reacting to rotation or position changes computed by an animator.
To use dynamics, configure one or more dynamic behaviors—including providing each with a set of dynamic items—and then add those behaviors to a dynamic animator.
You specify dynamic behaviors using any of the iOS primitive dynamic behavior classes:
, and
. Each of these provides configuration options and lets you associate one or more dynamic items to the behavior. To activate a behavior, add it to an animator.
A dynamic animator interacts with each of its dynamic items as follows:
Before adding an item to a behavior, you specify the item’s starting position, rotation, and bounds (to do so, use properties of the item’s class, such as the
, and
properties in the case of a
-based item)
After you add the behavior to an animator, the animator takes over: it updates the item’s position and rotation as animation proceeds (see the
protocol)
You can programmatically update an item’s state in the midst of an animation, after which the animator takes back control of the item’s animation, relative to the state you specified (see the
method)
You can define composite behaviors using the
method of the
parent behavior class. The set of behaviors you add to an animator constitute a behavior hierarchy. Each behavior instance you associate with an animator can be present only once in the hierarchy.

To employ a dynamic animator, first identify the type of dynamic items you want to animate. This choice determines which initializer to call, and this in turn determines how the coordinate system gets set up. The three ways to initialize an animator, the dynamic items you can then use, and the resulting coordinate system, are as follows:
To animate views, create an animator with the
method. The coordinate system of the reference view serves as the coordinate system for the animator’s behaviors and items. Each dynamic item you associate with this sort of animator must be a
object and must descend from the reference view.
You can define a boundary, for items participating in a collision behavior, relative to the bounds of the reference view. See the
method.
To animate collection views, create an animator with the
method. The resulting animator employs a collection view layout (an object of the
class) for its coordinate system. The dynamic items in this sort of animator must be
objects that are part of the layout.
You can define a boundary, for items participating in a collision behavior, relative to the bounds of the collection view layout. See the
method.
A collection view animator automatically calls the
method as needed, and automatically pauses and resumes animation, as appropriate, when you change a collection view’s layout.
To employ a dynamic animator with other objects that conform to the
protocol, create an animator with the inherited
method. The resulting animator employs an abstract coordinate system, not tied to the screen or to any view.

There is no reference boundary to refer to when defining a collision boundary for use with this sort of animator. However, you can still, in a collision behavior, specify custom boundaries as described in
All types of dynamic animators share the following characteristics:
Each dynamic animator is independent of other dynamic animators you create
You can associate a given dynamic item with multiple behaviors, provided those behaviors belong to the same animator
An animator automatically pauses when all its items are at rest, and automatically resumes when a behavior parameter changes or a behavior or item is added or removed
You can implement a delegate to respond to changes in animator pause/resumption status, using the
and
methods of the
protocol.

abstract.text: Implemented by subclasses to initialize a new object (the receiver) immediately after memory for it has been allocated.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A relationship between two dynamic items, or between a dynamic item and an anchor point.
An abstract base class for generating layout information for a collection view.
Invalidates the current layout and triggers a layout update.
A layout object that manages the layout-related attributes for a given item in a collection view.
An object that confers to a specified array of dynamic items the ability to engage in collisions with each other and with the behavior’s specified boundaries.
Specifies a collision boundary based on the bounds of the animation reference system, with optional insets.
An object that provides physics-related capabilities and animations for its dynamic items, and provides the context for those animations.
Adds a dynamic behavior to a dynamic animator.
The dynamic behaviors managed by a dynamic animator.
The delegate for responding to pausing or resumption of animation.
Returns the time interval since the dynamic animator started running.
Initializes a dynamic animator with a specified collection view layout.
Initializes a dynamic animator with a specified view as its reference view.
Returns true if the dynamic animator is running.
Returns the dynamic items, from the animator’s behaviors, that intersect a specified rectangle.
A convenience method for returning the layout attributes for a collection view cell.
A convenience method for returning the layout attributes for a collection view decoration view.
A convenience method for returning the layout attributes for a collection view supplementary view.
The view that a dynamic animator was initialized with.
Removes all of the dynamic behaviors from a dynamic animator.
Removes a specified dynamic behavior from a dynamic animator.
Asks a dynamic animator to read the current state of a dynamic item, replacing the animator’s internal representation of the item’s state.
To respond to the pausing or resumption of UIKit dynamic animation, configure a custom class to adopt the
protocol. Then, in a dynamic animator (an instance of the
class), set the delegate to be an instance of your custom class.
Called when a dynamic animator pauses the animations for its behaviors’ associated dynamic items.
Called when a dynamic animator is about to resume the animations for its behaviors’ associated dynamic items.
An object that confers a behavioral configuration on one or more dynamic items, for their participation in 2D animation.
Adds a dynamic behavior, as a child, to a custom dynamic behavior.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A base dynamic animation configuration for one or more dynamic items.
An object that applies a gravity-like force to all of its associated dynamic items.
A behavior that applies a continuous or instantaneous force to one or more dynamic items, causing those items to change position accordingly.
A spring-like behavior whose initial motion is damped over time so that the object settles at a specific point.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
The bounds rectangle, which describes the view’s location and size in its own coordinate system.
The center point of the view’s frame rectangle.
Specifies the transform applied to the view, relative to the center of its bounds.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
